awd_titl_txt: OP: Full Temporal Characterization of Interacting Photon Wavefunctions Using Real-Time Multi-Mode Quantum Measurements
awd_abstract_narration:
The field of quantum information science is rapidly advancing because of the anticipated impacts that will come from new quantum technologies such as secure communication protocols, improved measurement systems, and revolutionary computing methods.  Many of these technologies require nonlinear optical phenomena and sources of correlated light quanta, or photons.  This project will pioneer new ways to generate and characterize complex quantum states of light. One aim is to use optical cavities surrounding a sample of cold atoms in order to enhance the way one light beam can control the phase shift for another light beam.   A second aim is to use a graphical processor unit (GPU) for real-time characterization of quantum states of light.  This will serve as a benchmarking tool for quantum networks, and allow on-the-fly tuning of operational parameters in sophisticated networks of quantum gates and memories.  Developing tools for real-time characterization of quantum networks trains students working on this project to use cutting-edge technologies from computer engineering, atomic physics, and photonics.

This research has three main thrusts. First, the deployment of different novel physical platforms in which single-photon level quantum nonlinearities can be observed. Second, the design and implementation of state-of-the-art characterization tools that make it possible to explore the quantum process tomography of the gate processes in an extended Hilbert space.  Third, the realization of experiments to develop reliable quantum gate operations with single photon fields. An overarching goal of this project is to understand the physics governing atom-mediated photon-photon interactions in a framework with multiple optical frequency modes.  To study the performance of quantum phase gates, the team will use GPU hardware to develop quantum state evaluation tools.  This approach will also enable real-time characterization of phase-shift operations using interacting photons.

por.por_cntn:
Presently, the field of quantum networking is among the most incessantly pursued research areas due to the technological impact a realized distributed quantum processing network would convey. The availability of a trustworthy quantum network would revamp numerous aspects of science and engineering, including: the development of ultra-secure communication channels, and the materialization of powerful distributed quantum computers. There are three key milestones that must be attained in order for an error-corrected distributed quantum processing network based on light and atoms to come to fruition. First, is the availability of on-demand, quantum light sources that are both of narrow bandwidth and are conveniently tunable to atomic transitions. Second, is the development of reliable light-matter interconnects that can deterministically receive and reproduce quantum light states (quantum memories). The final milestone calls for an enormous increase in complexity as it requires the realization of a sophisticated quantum interface to perform logic gates composed of two qubits (quantum gates).

This grant allowed us to further develop a research program targeted at delivering these key quantum devices, necessary to construct advanced atomic-based quantum networks. Our main goals were: 1) Constructing low-noise, high- fidelity quantum light matter interfaces in which to create robust atomic collective excitations, 2) Designing and implementing sources of quantum light tuned to atomic transitions, ready for interfacing with atomic ensembles and 3) Creating and fully characterizing optically-driven photon-photon non-linearities created in atomic ensembles. Together, these technologies form the backbone of near future quantum repeater networks.

More specifically, we performed theoretical analysis of a double-lambda closed loop atomic system as a medium for non-linear optics at the single photon level, including Doppler broadening in a room temperature ensemble. Using this knowledge, we implemented a double-lambda closed loop atomic system and experimentally demonstrated few-photon-level triggered, single photon level pi-phase shifts in warm rubidium vapor. This is the first time that this exquisite level of photon-photon non-linearities have been shown at room temperature. Our results were published in: "Conditional Pi-Phase Shift of Single-Photon-Level Pulses at Room Temperature", Phys. Rev. Lett. 125, 243601 (2020).

Additionally, we successfully developed twin-photon sources based upon optical parametric amplifiers, capable of producing 10^5 photon pairs with a very narrow linewidth of 3 MHz, precisely tuned to emit on resonance with the rubidium D1 line. Furthermore, we also develop a novel double-cavity ensemble QED systems, in which two optical modes are coupled to the same cold atomic ensemble. This allowed us to realize the first demonstration of simultaneous double vacuum Rabi splitting in a rubidium ensemble. Both of these achievements are the core of two articles that are in the final stages of preparation.

The support from this grant also allow the PI Figueroa to work in a theoretical project and a community review, which have been recently published in: "Entanglement generation in a quantum network with finite quantum memory lifetime", AVS Quantum Science 4, 01200 (2022) and "The potential and global outlook of integrated photonics for quantum technologies" Nature Reviews Physics 4, 194 (2022).

Lastly, the grant allowed us to train five graduate students and three undergraduate students in all aspects of quantum information science and technology using atomic systems.
